snippet: An unlikely meeting was set for Monday in Vienna, a meeting that could dramatically affect the economic contours of the upcoming Facebook deal . Two Facebook executives were scheduled to meet with Max Schrems, 24, a law student from Vienna, who has...
abstract: An unlikely meeting was set for Monday in Vienna, a meeting that could dramatically affect the economic contours of the upcoming Facebook deal . Two Facebook executives were scheduled to meet with Max Schrems, 24, a law student from Vienna, who has led the charge in Europe against what he says are Facebook's illegal practices of saving - and marketing - the personal data of users, often without their consent.
lead_paragraph: The numbers surrounding the upcoming public offering of Facebook shares are staggering - billions here, billions there, and it's all beginning to add up to real money. Meanwhile, as my colleague Kevin O'Brien reports, a meeting that could dramatically affect the economic contours of the deal was set for Monday in Vienna.

headline.main: Clicking the 'Not Like' Button in Europe
